author: superluminal0
content:
I'm trying to wrap my head around how any changes can be implemented against the will of the miners (1559, POS, or anything else).

The big miners can run a custom client without those changes, and with a majority of the hashrate under their control the custom client will define the cannonical chain.

It's even worse when you try an "ice age" mechanism, because miners running the ice age implementation will find fewer blocks with the same hashrate than miners who have removed the ice age from their client.

author: sky.cactus
content: With a hard fork it is rather easy.  Miners can mine whatever they want, and everyone will just ignore it.

author: sky.cactus
content: The canonical chain is the longest chain that follows the set of rules that your local client believes are true.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is *not* the longest chain regardless of the ruleset being followed.

author: superluminal0
content: If the 6 biggest mining pools all run a client that keeps the rules exactly as they are now then they will easily build the longest chain and define consensus among themselves.

author: sky.cactus
content: Yep, and they can mine that forever.  That doesn't mean anyone will care.  ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: Every individual Ethereum user runs a client (or delegates the operation of their client to someone else).  These clients have a set of rules.  Any block that is produced that aligns with those rules is eligible to be considered part of the "longest chain" as seen by that client.  Blocks that do not follow the rules that client has will simply be ignored and any peer that sends such a block will likely be disconnected from.

author: sky.cactus
content: You can create a coalition of miners that has 1000x the hash rate of the current miners who all decide to mine blocks following a new set of rules, and these blocks will all be ignored by anyone not running that same set of rules.

author: sky.cactus
content: The net effect of this is that miners mine blocks against the set of rules that they believe is most valuable either short term (for miners that sell their earnings right away) or long term (for miners who hold their earnings).

author: sky.cactus
content: Miners don't *really* have much of a say in what rules are followed, they follow the money.

author: superluminal0
content:
That's a lot of text, but the gist of it seems to be that you agree with me.

If a supermajority of the block finders all agree on some set of rules then those are the rules.

author: sky.cactus
content: No, that is the opposite of what I am saying.

author: sky.cactus
content: If *users* of the platform choose to follow a particular set of rules, then that is the rules that will be followed.  Anyone (including miners) can fork away from the majority of *users*.

author: superluminal0
content:
?
Users don't elongate the blockchain, miners do.
If you read that research paper about the perils of fee-based incentives you will see that it is all based on the ability to decide which block to build on.

A coalition of the biggest miners can run clients that build on each other's blocks, thereby defining the longest chain.

How can a user change that with some unique cryptokitty attire?
